bibl.title: Letter from Edward R. Stitt to Philip Showalter Hench, January 2, 1947

div1.p: Stitt informs Hench that Carter's sister, Mary Carter, thinks she sent the papers collected by Stitt's late wife, Laura Armistead Carter Stitt, to Carter's son in Birmingham, Alabama. He gives Hench the address of Carter's son and offers to help Hench gain access to George Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from Edward R. Stitt to Philip Showalter Hench, January 2, 1947

1625 R St. N. W.
???
WASHINGTON ??? D. C
January 2, 1947

div1.p:
I am very much obliged
to you for the photograph.

The two address I gave you were the flg.:
(1) Miss Mary C. Carter, care of H. Carter Redd,
Ashland, Hanover Co., Va. Miss Carter
was a sister of Dr. H. R. Carter, of the
Public Health Service, and, although,
probably, approaching 80, is still a very
brilliant woman and was the closest
friend, as well as relation of Laura Carter
Stitt. Mrs. Stitt did not have a sister-
Her brother, a prominent physician (cardiologist)
of Birmingham, Ala., has records of his
father. I think I told you that after
Mrs. Stitt's death I supposed that her aunt
had gone over the letter etc. that Laura
had collected but, apparently there was failure
to find the particular papers while Laura
had collected. Miss Mary Carter had an
idea that she had sent the important
papers (left in Ashland) to Dr. Henry Carter.
over
C1
B3

(2) Doctor Henry Rose Carter,
805 Woodward Building
Birmingham, Ala.

I asked Dr. Oscar Hunter, a prominent
pathologist of Washington, about the possibility
of his getting in touch with young Carroll,
but he said he only was associated
with Dr. Carroll as a student at Geo.
Washington Medical School.

You may know of some medical
man who may have the confidence of
the Carroll fam. If so, I may be
able to help in the matter of Carroll's
papers.

Please remember me to Admiral
Craig and Commander Mayeth_
Wishing you a pleasant 1947, I am,
